answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
I found some information about other shared services governance models.
Below is a case study from the University of North Carolina about, Using 'Corporate-Style' Benchmarking to Improve the Performance of Local Governments: Examining the Development Review Process.
http://icma.org/en/Article/11953/Case_Study_University_of_North_Carolina_Administered_Project
The California Department of Technological Resources has created a PowerPoint presentation about shared services governance models which discusses the challenges and opportunities of such a program as well as best practices.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/301712 
San Mateo, California also put together a memo discussing the benefits of their proposed program.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/13709
Another article which might be helpful in regards to your question about HR and overtime is, It’s a Jungle Out There: Your Three Biggest Human Resource Pitfalls, by the Florida League of Cities.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/5859/Its_a_Jungle_Out_There_Your_Three_Biggest_Human_Resource_Pitfalls
Ali Iannolo 
Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

author: Lisa Callas
text:
Hi,
As part of a review of our shared services governance model, I'm exploring the various ways that groups manage accountability.
SLA's tend to come up as a tool for service delivery but what about oversight at a higher level? For example what responsibility does the HR group have for monitoring and reporting excessive overtime? What role does IT have if a department purchases software without approval that isn't in line with the IT strategic direction? 
I'd really enjoy hearing how other areas manage this type of challenge.
title: Accountability & Shared Services
